#TheTweetingNun

22/04/2013

Sister Anne, a.k.a @nunblogger talks to Fiona Parker about life as a late-teen in a convent, the history of The Daughters of St. Paul and the role of the individual voice within the Catholic faith.

Image by

By undefined undefined

I had always assumed that the life of a nun was a rather private affair. That their unimaginable strength to endure a life which commits to the pillars of chastity, poverty and faultless obedience to their God, formed existences which were lost in translation to those outside the sisterhood. I am not a Catholic, but I have always been fascinated by the secret lives of nuns, their lifelong sacrifices and of course, their faith, which is so powerful that it is the focal point of their lives. I was forced to cast away this shamelessly romanticised image whilst scrolling through my Twitter newsfeed and coming across a username which consisted of two words which I would never have guessed would sit comfortably together - @nunblogger. Two weeks later, I was face-to-face (via a Skype connection to Chicago) with a 56-year-old, social media-savvy Sister Anne, of the Daughters of St. Paul. "I joined because at 18 I realised that "Jesus and the media" summed up my whole interior focus". The Daughters of St. Paul are a unique group of nuns, who, founded in Alba in 1915, aim to bring the Word of God to the world through "the most rapid and effective means that progress provides and the necessities and conditions of the times require" - "Well", Sister interjects, "at least that's what was phrased on the official documents submitted to the Vatican". Before I found out exactly how an institution set up by a diocesan priest had led to a tweeting nun, I had a feeling that my former assumptions of life behind the convent doors were about to be disassembled within minutes. "My mom tells me I used to talk about being a nun when I was really tiny, I'm talking kindergarten!" Perhaps such strength of faith really is an innate quality? "I really don't remember that at all!" It was at this point that I was forced to accept Sister Anne, not as an unconventional nun, but as a conventional human being.
"When I was young and beautiful Muslim men used to flirt with us!"
In reality, life for the late teen in a convent was, as it would be for anybody else, far from easy. "We were all getting used to the various aspects of convent life. We had to keep daily schedules, accept assignments and learn the ways of prayer in our community. There were a few "convent ways", now abrogated, that were really ridiculous. You couldn't wear wrist watches because fifty years beforehand they had been considered vain." Unsurprisingly, the young woman often found herself biting her lip in response to several of the strict rules and regulations of a nun's life. "I remember one time, a fellow postulant who had entered a few months before I did, corrected me about the way I was doing some inconsequential thing. "Here, we do it this way," she said, demonstrating the "convent way" of proceeding. I didn't answer out loud because my response would have been something along the lines of, "Why does every little thing have to be so damn different?"" The nun's habit, a simple skirt and blouse with something similar to a waistcoat which hangs elegantly on the shoulders, is the distinctive uniform of the Daughters of St. Paul. "The habit was and remains important to me. In my youth, even though I did not like the style of the Daughters of St. Paul habit, it told me that the sisters had a secure sense of identity. Now, as the media contributes to an excessively visual culture, I think that the aesthetic value of the habit is more important than ever." I can't restrain myself from asking Sister further questions about her views on the fashion value of the habit in her younger days. The edges of her lips quiver as she suppresses a smile before beginning one particular anecdote. "When I was young and beautiful, doing door-to-door book ministries with a fellow young sister, Muslim men used to flirt with us. Years on, I attended a concert in honour of the Virgin Mary. Whilst I was there, I caught sight of some Persian women who were chanting the Koranic texts about Mary. They looked just like nuns." Almost a century ago, when the Daughters of St. Paul was in its early stages, Sister Anne tells me that despite the fact that the printed press was the only obvious form of media, the founder, Blessed James Alberione encouraged the sisters to look beyond the newspapers and into other forms of communication. "You are not tied to the printing press alone. Use whatever inventions arise that can be put at the service of the Gospel!" With this kind of philosophy in mind, it is not a surprise that the Daughters have harnessed the power of social media. "But the media is not just a tool", Sister insists, "it's a form of culture and it's part of our mission to engage that media culture with the message of the Gospel and to equip people of goodwill to contribute to that culture in a way that respects human dignity." But how do the Daughters engage with culture? "We have sisters who act as consultants for movies and television shows, while others write movie reviews or are screenwriters." What started as a small group of women in Italy, has become what Sister Anne describes as a "global enterprise", with over 2, 500 sisters spread across 55 countries. She goes on to explain that as the organisation functions within areas and communities which are on different scales both culturally and economically, the Daughters have learnt to adapt to their environments. "In the 1930s Brazil was plagued with widespread illiteracy. The sisters there focused on creating audio recordings and posters which were used in Sunday schools. In Korea, our sisters developed a marvellous correspondence course on Scripture. In the Philippines, the Daughters run a kind of school for training ministry personnel in media." But what kind of things does Sister Anne tweet about? Recently her profile has been a mass of retweets of articles which document the trial of Dr Kermit Gosnell, a former owner of an abortion clinic, who has been charged with eight counts of murder; one of an immigrant woman and seven of newborn babies. Gosnell's methods included his infamous "snipping technique". Mothers at a late stage in pregnancy would be induced into early labour, before the baby's spinal cord was cut with a pair of scissors. "But truth-tellers get punished sometimes," the Sister stresses, "they get marginalized and they get harassed."
"Since he was only a couple of hours drive from Chicago, I fully expected him to show up one day to teach me a lesson."
Not everybody, of course, takes the Bible for its word and I was anxious to learn about the kind of criticism which Sister Anne deals with on a daily basis. It is undeniable that so many of the aspects of life which Catholics and Atheists disagree on are arguably the foundations of individual moral being: sex, marriage, birth and death. "I don't go into a lot of specifics on these issues, but sometimes even an oblique reference will trigger a defensive reaction from people who seem to be reading an awful lot into what I write." Sister Anne often fears that these "defensive reactions" will turn into full-blown personal attacks. "I have been chastised for "condemning people to hell", which is something I never, ever, ever even think about, much less write. There was one respondent who frightened me with his vehemence. Since he was only a couple of hour's drive from Chicago, I fully expected him to show up one day to teach me a lesson!" But if this individual was to violate Illinois speeding restrictions before thumping his knuckles on Sister Anne's front door, he would, in my opinion, have to first work out whether he was insulted by the beliefs of the Church she belongs to or by her own individual voice. In the light of Pope Francis's inauguration, there was the inevitable media fallout on his views: "Did Pope Francis really say that socialism causes misery?"; "Does he really think that gay adoption is discrimination against children?" and, of course, one for the wannabe-film script writers, "Was his clerical ambition fed by the never-to-heal heartbreak of his childhood sweetheart rejecting his proposal?" The media's obsession with the views of the new head of the Catholic Church, highlights just how easy it is to hear this individual's voice and to replicate it and reflect it onto every single member of the faith. Sister Anne believes that the extent to which communities do this is dependent on their own cultures. "People interpret the Pope according to their own experience. If they are used to having a figure of authority to speak for their own community, then they probably assume that everything the Pope says is also held by every Catholic." Individuals such as Sister Anne, who prefer to step out and represent themselves rather than to allow their community to speak for them, ask the world to see religious followers as critics who analyse and speak as well as listen. Sister claims that if she did not believe her "teachings" were in accordance with the Pope's, she would have to "re-examine" her position. "The Pope has access to the situation across the globe, whereas my personal experience is limited." My heart sinks as I start to think that her moral compass really is a replica of what she has been told is right, until she fills my contemplative silence with a reiteration which changes all of that - "Not his views, but his teachings." Then I blush, a mark of embarrassment that I can only hope the poor quality of my Skype camera does not reveal in high definition. For how could I have doubted the personal insight of a woman, whose Twitter account is an active and living fusion of a publicly broadcasted religious belief and a vulnerable and ultimately human individual life? There is a retweet from @ThrivingMosaic: "Sad to hear of the passing of a long-time GSPN supporter and encourager, Richard Emblem. Praying for his family!" There are a number of "Pope-quotes". This one comes from @nativitypastor: "Lukewarm Christians are those who want to build a church to their own specifications, but it is not the Church of Christ - Pope Francis." Then there is a tweet from @nunblogger herself: "Rushing back to hospital. Mum's oxygen levels dropping. Visiting hrs just ended. Hope they let us in." When I ask Sister Anne whether she finds comfort in tweeting about her mother, who is critically ill with pneumonia, she responds in a controlled manner. "It is all I can write about at the moment, since it is what I am living through. I hope it won't be too boring, or "TMI" for my readers." Not all of us would agree with Sister Anne's views, but I can't help but think that there is something refreshing about listening to the voice of an individual nun rather than to a press statement given from the Vatican City. As we near the end of the interview, I am unable to hold back the gossip girl within me any longer. I decide to ask Sister just what she thought about Pope Francis's former marriage proposal. Immediately the 56-year-old woman is transformed into the young, strong-minded and passionate newbie-nun of thirty years ago. "What is the big deal? We are talking about a normal human being here! Even Pope Benedict wrote about his youthful discernment and whether or not he could live through the demands of celibacy if he were to follow a call to priesthood. Celibacy doesn't mean a person doesn't have feelings and desires, it means that they have made a commitment to deal with those feelings and desires!" I am silenced, the Sister has spoken. Sister Anne's mother passed away at 10.45 on 21st April. She was surrounded by six of her seven children.
